summary: Email chain between US Department of Justice officials discussing an MLAT request to the UK for travel records related to the Maxwell case (182-73090). The correspondence focuses on obtaining British Airways passenger data and manifests, with details on CBP record retention policies and data fields available.

persons.name: John McNeil
persons.role: U.S. Department of Justice Attaché - London
persons.context: DOJ official in London coordinating the MLAT request to the UK for travel records in the Maxwell case. He provides information on CBP record retention and forwards communications.

persons.name: Lara
persons.context: Attorney from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) leading the request for British Airways travel records for the Maxwell investigation.

persons.name: Taylor Cole
persons.context: DOJ attorney copied on the email chain regarding the MLAT request for travel records in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Jennifer Schroeder-Fawcett
persons.context: U.S. Customs and Border Protection attaché in London who provides technical details about APIS data fields and record availability for travel manifests.

connections.description: McNeil is assisting Lara with obtaining UK travel records through an MLAT request for the Maxwell investigation.
McNeil consults with Schroeder-Fawcett, the CBP attaché, about availability of British Airways travel records.
Both are DOJ attorneys working on the Maxwell case, with Cole copied on the correspondence about travel records.

events.title: CBP Technical Information Provided
events.description: Jennifer Schroeder-Fawcett provides detailed APIS data field information to John McNeil regarding what travel record information CBP might have available.

events.title: MLAT Request Drafting
events.description: Lara sends a draft MLAT request to John McNeil for obtaining British Airways travel records from the UK for the Maxwell investigation.

events.title: Final Review of MLAT Request
events.description: John McNeil returns a draft MLAT request with comments and questions, noting he will be out for a week and requesting turnaround by COB.

locations: United States Embassy, 33 Nine Elms Lane, London SW11 7US, United Kingdom
keyFacts: The document references case number 182-73090, which is the Maxwell case (Ghislaine Maxwell).
CBP destroys PNR (Passenger Name Record/ticketing) data after 5 years but retains flight manifest information for much longer periods.
The investigation is seeking British Airways travel records, potentially including private aircraft arrivals data from before 2009.
APIS data fields include comprehensive passenger information: full name, date of birth, passport details, address in the US, and travel itinerary details.
The correspondence shows active coordination between US prosecutors and law enforcement attachés in London to obtain foreign travel records via MLAT.
